description:
This course aims at introducing different aspects of research theory and practice as well as different types of research methods that are commonly used. It will focus on research methods used in language-related studies, but is not restricted to them. 

Moreover, the research methods introduced in this course will be applicable not only in academic studies but also in workplace when research is needed for further development and improvement. 

More importantly, this course helps students to think clearly when developing their own research topics and to evaluate the arguments made as well as the methods employed by their peers.

**Course Description**

This course aims at introducing different aspects of research theory and practice and at helping you to understand what is involved in carrying a research project. The finished product of this course is a research proposal of your own with some initial result from a pilot study.

As we introduce basics of research methods in general, these methods should be applicable in academic studies as well as in your future workplace when research is needed for further development and improvement. In addition to learning how to carrying out a research project, more importantly, being familiar with the methods for doing research will also help you to think clearly and to be able to critically analyze the claims and arguments made by other people.

June, E. H. (2003). The effects of organization markers on ESL Learners’ text understanding. _TESOL Quarterly_, _37_, 4, 749-759.

Amuzie, G. L. & Winkie, P. (2009). Changes in language learning belief as a result of study abroad. _System_, _37_, 366–379

Yu, L.T., Liou, H. C., & Vongpumivitch, V. (2013). Technology and Language: Quantitative Methods. In _The Encyclopedia of Applied Linguistics_, Carol A. Chapelle (Ed.) 1-8. Blackwell Publishing.

**Class Policies**

1\. Students are expected to attend each class—attendance will be taken. Multiple absences may result in an automatic failing grade.

2\. Students who miss class are responsible for content. Any student who misses a class has the responsibility for obtaining copies of notes, handouts, assignments, etc.

3\. The proposal must be double-spaced, using Times New Roman or Arial font. All font sizes for typed assignments must be size 12. Any font size less or more than 12 will be returned for re-typing to required font size.

4\. Academic honesty is expected at all times. **Plagiarism will result in a serious grade penalty and may lead to an automatic failing grade**.
